header.title: Angry dad confronts Boris Johnson after baby almost died
header.postText: The parent of a sick baby claimed the NHS was being ‘destroyed’ as he challenged Boris Johnson during a hospital visit.', 'The Prime Minister was confronted by a distressed dad as he visited a London hospital to see the reality of public services under his leadership.', 'The parent, identified as local labour activist Omar Salem, claimed there were not enough doctors and nurses and said his seven-day old daughter ‘nearly died yesterday’.', 'In a conversation lasting around two minutes, the man said the situation was ‘not acceptable’ and asked the PM ‘Would you like that for your own children?’.', 'The dad told the Prime Minister: ‘There are not enough people on this ward, there are not enough doctors, there’s not enough nurses, it’s not well organised enough.', '‘The NHS has been destroyed … and now you come here for a press opportunity.’', 'A baffled Boris responds by saying  ‘there’s no press here’ but the parent gestured to cameras filming the confrontation.', 'He said: ‘What do you mean there’s no press here, who are these people?’', 'Johnson explained he was ‘here to find out’ about the situation.', 'The man replies: ‘It’s a bit late isn’t it? Years and years and years of the NHS being destroyed.’', 'Johnson was visiting Whipps Cross University Hospital in north-east London when he was challenged by the parent on a children’s ward.', 'The nature of the young girl’s condition was not clear from the exchange.', 'The dad said ‘A&E guys were great’ but that followed a two hour wait on another ward for treatment.', 'He said: ‘This ward is not safe for children. There was one registrar covering the entirety of this ward and the neonatal unit.’', 'A spokesman for the Prime Minister said Mr Johnson was visiting public services to see for himself the reality of the situation.', 'The spokesman said the man was understandably ‘very distressed’.', 'He said the PM was ‘not going to hide away from those circumstances when he goes on these visits, and so obviously is keen to talk to people and empathise and see what he can do to help’.', 'He added: ‘It’s also a reminder of why exactly he is so keen to make the NHS a priority and make sure it’s getting the funding that it requires’.', 'Responding to Omar Salem’s claim there were not enough doctors and nurses on a children’s ward, Alan Gurney, chief executive of Whipps Cross hospital, said: ‘We are constantly reviewing staffing levels on our wards to ensure our patients are safe at all times, but occasionally – as in fact happened on this ward last night- an unexpected emergency in one part of the hospital can cause a temporary pressure elsewhere.’
header.socioLingVar: Ideological and Political Identity - General,Nationality - European or anti-Europeans,Age - Over 65s,Physical Identity - Physical (and Mental) Impairments,Age - Youngsters,Nationality - General

commentThread.commentText: Another idiot making a scene. Yes the NHS is struggling but it wasn't Boris who did it, and complaining in a hospital big man, just made yourself look like are right txxt.

replies.commentText: It wasn't Johnson, but it is the Tories, specifically Hunt,  who have set the NHS on the road to ruin.

What do you mean? Johnson is a member of the government who created this situation. He must share blame. And he has only announced he is putting more money into the NHS- it remains to see it it happens. Probably won't be that legendary £350 M he claimed Brexit would save,

I wouldn't call a man who's clearly upset his little daughter nearly died an idiot. Hardly fair to a man in an emotional state. The fact is the NHS is understaffed and overworked. Whether we know or fully understand the beauracratic processes in place another. People want someone to talk to and blame and Boris is the current PM. The tories have been trying to Privatise the NHS for sometime, and although parts seem fine with charging and I agree that there are too many people now demanding services, there are cuts there are charges incurred to the NHS that they can't afford, there is understaffing and we are relient on workers from abroad as we have less and less people in the UK chosing it as a career. It's also over managed, way too much paper work and less on floor teams and Matrons looking after wards. I'm not saying Boris is bad or good, |'m saying we need to do alot more for our services NHS included, it's easy to diss it but when it's gone we won't all be able to pay for the costs of often lifesaving or changing care, and if Brexit really does mean a larger disparity between rich and poor, a higher mortality rate and rather a grim outlook
Oscar James actually it was labour who screwed up by over spending and getting this country in the red .>

Do you understand the concept of being an MP representing a specific party? It is very simple (maybe you are too), if you are part of a party then you share its aims and policies, but you also take (big word coming here, take your time and sound it out) responsibility for its actions. In this case, the actions of the tories have been to consitently cut funding for the NHS and involve private concerns who are more motivated by short term profit than quality of care.

commentThread.commentText: And actually he's putting more money into the NHS than any other parties have done.

replies.commentText: He has said he will. We are yet to see it. The Tories have done so much to purposefully destroy the NHS to justify privatisation. If they actually made big companies pay their full tax there would be enough money but they won't. The Tories claimed getting Google to pay 3% tax was a win when they are supposed to pay between 20 and 30% tax. They've given huge tenders to private conpanies over NHS bids despite using the same equipment and NHS staff training the private company's staff. Brexit will make this worse too. Especially on a no deal. A quarter of NHS staff are EU immigrants. The Tories cut the nursing bursary straight after the referendum results. Where are we going to get our nurses and doctors from? Medication supply is already being affected. Stop bein g blind to the reality of the situation and what they are doing. Tories hate public services and love privatisation. Each day more and more of it being privatised without people noticing because of the bloody B word. I work in the NHS so I see what they have done to it. It's appalling.

Kate Auriol Johnson Hornby absolute Labour propoganda nonsense.  Yeat or year the NHS has had real increases and still haemoraging cash.  Blame UNCONTROLLED IMMIGRATION and the hundreds of PRIVATE Funded Initiatives Labour signed us up to!
£350 mil a week?
Dan Petre have we left yet?
Lies, lies and more lies, are you sure your not Boris?

Do you not realise that even with real increased funding over last few years, PFI agreements take a quarter of some NHS Trusts annual budgets!  Oh and just for the record, I'm very happy for skilled immigration. Boris, you jest, he's probably the most liberal Tory PM ever, but you're probably too blinkered to even realise that.

commentThread.commentText: It’s not the government. The NHS is just destroying itself, crumbling under the weight of lefty libturd bureaucracy, incompetent management and greedy pharmaceuticals suppliers who hold the medical trusts over a barrel with their over-priced products. It's the patients and front-line staff who end up suffering. The left are in complete denial and prefer to keep blaming the right for the problems their "all for one and one for all" socialist culture is causing.The NHS, as it is now, needs to be completely dismantled and rebuilt from scratch with the *right* medically qualified people at its helm to work in the 21st Century and beyond. Not beancounters and tickbox management who apply management principles from other irrelevant industries to the hospitals and got parachuted in to deliver cost-cutting initiatives that do more damage than good.

replies.commentText: Exactly,   and the nutto left want to bring this to the US,  scary

So privatising huge sections of the NHS is not responsible? With 100s of NHS departments having to make a profit you don't think services will suffer?. Still- Boris reckons there will be £350M available so all will be solved. Not holding my breath though.

Oscar James Privatisation means a private company provides a service for a contract fee or a per treatment fee. This happens already in large parts of the NHS and nothing has imploded. Private companies work more efficiently and with less "public sector bloat" so can provide the exact same service quality as the NHS but at a much lower price. Some of the saving is taken as profit, some returned as saving on the contract value.Privatisation is the only way the NHS will survive. There's too many people on the NHS money train now, taking hideous money out of the NHS for very little value, and certainly very little patient care.

"It’s not the government. The NHS is just destroying itself, crumbling under the weight of lefty libturd bureaucracy"And who has been running the NHS for the last nine years, the Government or "lefty libturds"?It's the governement, isn't it? The one that has had a Tory at the helm for the last nine years and counting.You dumb c*nt.
Ming Lang - Even at its worst, out healthcare system helps more people than yours.And causes fewer deaths."Scary", but only to the "uninformed".

Lance Del Monte not true. The Tories have been giving the tenders to more expensive private companies over NHS. In one case the private company (which happened to have a Tory MP on its board) cost £7million more than the NHS bid. They are using equipment which the local community raised funds for. The NHS staff that were using the scanner had to train the private company's staff how to use it. Can you explain to me why they would go for a bid that cost 7million more, using the same equipment and NHS trained staff? It's not even that unusual. They are giving bit by bit to the private sector every day and it's not always cheaper. They are killing it to justify 100% privatisation. I work alongside NHS staff and am based in an NHS building. I see what they've done since they came into power and believe me it is so much worse.

Kate Auriol Johnson Hornby I'm sceptical of your claims.  Services are commissioned by the NHS directly, there's little or no government involvement. There are NHS procurement tenders which go out into the public domain, the choice of which has to be justified.  If what you're saying is true, it would be all over the press.

'lefty libturd bureaucracy'? There hasn't been a Labour government since 2010. If there's too much bureaucracy why have't the Tories done anything about it? What improvements have they made on this issue over the last 9 years? There's also nothing left wing or socialist about pharmacutical companies charging high prices to the NHS. That's supply and demand in the free market. In fact a left wing solution there would be for the gov to impose a price cap on what the NHS is willing to pay for any drug to these companies.
Amy Lawrence A price cap, lol and when the Pharmaceutical Cos tell us to go fiddle, what then?  You can't regulatr pricing in a free market.
Lance Del Monte You are correct but you shouldn't expect libtard zombies to believe anything unless spoken by Labour.

Depressing that so many people seem to either ignore what has happened or are ignorant to it. The problems in the NHS are caused by privatisation- a ludicrous situation where private corporations make a profit our of sick people and the taxpayer pays for those profits. While privatisation was put on steroids under Blair he was hardly a lefty and shouyld have been in the party where he'd feel right at home- the Conservatives.
Oscar James People say this about Blair but he was revered by all those Blairites (such as Hilary Benn and Yvette Cooper) that still exist within present day Corbyn's Labour party...
